Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Investigating the Ultrafast Charge Dynamics in Polymer Solar Cells Incorporating Nanostructured Silver Electrodes
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the search for sustainable energy sources, low energy consumption technologies are critical to minimize our environmental impact and maximize the energy harvested. Polymer solar cells are lightweight, flexible alternatives to traditional solar cells and have potential energy payback times as low as one day (compared to >2.5 years required for solar cells made from silicon), if their efficiency can reach >15%. One way to improve the efficiency of polymer solar cells is to employ light-trapping techniques, such as using nanostructured metallic electrodes. While polymer solar cells incorporating metallic nanostructures are known to have improved light absorption in the polymer active layer, this does not always translate to improved electrical output. This study seeks to fundamentally understand why improved light absorption does not necessarily lead to improved electrical output in the presence of nanostructured metallic electrodes. To do this, ultrafast time-resolved photoinduced absorption measurements will be conducted at Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology in collaboration with Professor Keshav Dani, who is an expert in conducting ultrafast time-resolved measurements.

Nanostructured Ag electrodes will be fabricated with the structure of Ag nanoparticle arrays on a Ag thin film (AgNPA/Ag). To mitigate the effects of charge recombination at the AgNPA surface, a series of ultrathin interfacial layers (exfoliated MoS2, Ag2O, and graphene oxide) will be applied to the AgNPA/Ag and compared to AgNPA/Ag without an interfacial layer. The prototypical polymer:fullerene blend, P3HT:PCBM, in which the photophysics are well-established, will be used as the active layer coating. Two-color pump-probe measurements will be employed, in which P3HT:PCBM will be optically pumped with a wavelength within its absorption band, and the probe wavelengths selected will be those corresponding to photoinduced absorption from P3HT excitons (bound electron-hole pairs) and P3HT:PCBM polarons (free electrons and holes) over a time scale of tens of fs to 1 ns. This will allow the elucidation of whether the initially improved population of excitons in the P3HT:PCBM layer translates to an improved polaron population, with the expectation that both exciton and polaron photoinduced absorption should both be greater in the presence of the passivated AgNPA/Ag, which would eventually translate to improved solar cell device efficiency. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific aim of this project was to develop an understanding of the mechanism by which hybrid nanomaterials can be used to improve the efficiency of polymer-based solar cells. There is a demand for low-cost, high-efficiency renewable energy sources to minimize anthropogenic greenhouse gas emission. Polymer-based solar cells have shown great promise as low-cost energy sources due to their reduced material waste, earth-abundant elemental constituents, and low energy-consumption production techniques. However, a major drawback of polymer-based solar cells is their low efficiency - having maximum reported efficiencies of ~10%, compared to those of Si solar cells, which can range from 20 - 27%. This project sought to incorporate various nanomaterials (i.e., two-dimensional materials and metallic nanostructures) in order to improve the light absorption and charge collection from polymer:fullerene absorbers, which are the charge-generating active layers in polymer-based solar cells. Transient pump-probe reflectometry was employed in order to investigate the charge generation and transfer properties of the polymer:fullerene layers in the presence of the nanomaterials at ultrafast time scales - i.e., time domains ranging from femtosecond (fs, 10-15 s) to picosecond (ps, 10-12 s) scales.

The nanomaterials and polymer:fullerene layers were prepared prior to the start of this project, at the PI's host institution (Rutgers University). This fellowship enabled the PI to travel to Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST) in order to use the state-of-the-art ultrafast optics facilities in the Femtosecond Spectroscopy Unit (see Figures 1-4). Through the 9 weeks spent at OIST, the transient pump-probe reflectometry measurements led to the conclusions that the hybrid nanomaterials enhanced charge generation within the polymer:fullerene layers by more than 600%, resulting from the synergistic effects of the two-dimensional material combined with the metallic nanostructures. These results, in addition to other steady-state optical measurements and simulations, are in the process of being disseminated to the public via a peer-reviewed publication and will be presented at the national Materials Research Society conference in Phoenix, AZ (March 2016).

Additionally, this fellowship has enabled a collaboration to be established between researchers at Rutgers University and OIST. The PI will return to OIST to continue working in the Femtosecond Spectroscopy Unit for 1 year in order to conduct more extensive ultrafast optoelectronic measurements of completed solar cell devices incorporating the designed hybrid nanomaterials. Other researchers from Rutgers University will continue to provide two-dimensional materials to the Femtosecond Spectroscopy Unit in order to study the ultrafast dynamics of charge carriers on the surface of the novel materials. The broader impacts of this fellowship included the PI receiving training in ultrafast optical spectroscopies and two-dimensional nanofabrication techniques, and having the opportunity to aid in mentoring 4 summer interns at OIST. The PI also participated in several educational outreach activities for the Child Development Center afterschool program at OIST, including making liquid nitrogen ice cream for the children (Figure 5; including an explanation of cryogenic liquids and states of matter) and explaining the atomic structure and periodic table to the students.
